column5: Michael Clements, Andrew Nolan, Jackson Powell
column8: BrainEx: Visual Exploration and Discovery of Sequence Similarity in Brain Signals
column10: BrainEx is a tool for exploring and comparing sequences in time series datasets with a focus of applications on brain data. BrainEx is the successor of the tools ONEX and GENEX. Our project seeks to extend BrainEx's graphical user interface with a cluster explorer, general usability improvements, and an integrated exploration pipeline between the cluster explorer, similarity search, and feature exploration tools. These improvements provide researchers with a powerful way to explore time series data. A user study and an expert review confirmed that BrainEx provides time series exploration in ways existing tools do not.

column8: Development and Assessment of a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction Mobile Application
column10: The goal of this Major Qualifying Project (MQP) is to continue development of a mobile platform to assist college students in the practice of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR). This project is a continuation of two previous Major Qualifying Projects (MQP) that conducted research and proposed designs for the app, and an Interactive Qualifying Project (IQP) that started development of the "doyoumindful" prototype application. The platform was improved upon by building a video player to stream video content, and creating an in-house events system to record app usage information. A user study of 30 participants was conducted to assess the effectiveness of the new video player, which also served to test the reliability of the back-end.

column8: Clustering Hippocampal Neuron Action Potentials Using Autoencoders and Autoencoder-Kalman Filtering for Noise Reduction
column10: In this project, we applied the deep learning methods of autoencoder-Kalman filtering as well as the autoencoder preprocessing from Ciecierski (2020) to improve clustering on action potentials by filtering noise. We used multiple types of clustering, including k-means clustering, mean-shift clustering, and agglomerative hierarchical clustering. We evaluated the performance of each clustering algorithm after using each filtering method, as well as no filtering, to analyze which of the filtering methods has the best effect on clustering action potentials.

The coordination between data analytics and database systems becomes exceedingly important in order to efficiently analyze data that is stored inside the database. This project compared two approaches that integrate machine learning with database systems: client-server connection and in-database processing. Two machine learning models - Support Vector Machine and Random Forest - were implemented using each of the approaches and then tested on datasets of different scales. After comparing the run-time efficiency and the testing accuracy of the two approaches, I generated the conclusion regarding which approach has better performance.

column8: GearTrain: Converting WinForms Gear Design Software to WPF
column10: The goal of this project is to convert gear design software made in a previous MQP from the outdated Windows Forms graphics framework to the newer WPF framework, and improve it. Through many user studies, we were able to determine how users responded to the software to see what changes should be made. Users recommended that a 3D representation of the gear train design be added, so that was included in the system. After many iterative refinement steps through the User Interface and program flow, our users generally agree that our new program, titled GearTrain, is a significant improvement over the previous system. GearTrain teaches Mechanical Engineering students about gear concepts and simplifies the design of gear trains.

column5: Samatha Grillo, Kalani Picho, Kenneth Rhodes, Alec Kneedler
column6: Marko Popovic, George Heineman, Gregory Fischer
column7: Computer Science,Electrical & Computer Engineering,Mechanical Engineering,Robotics Engineering
column10: The goal of this MQP was to design, fabricate, and implement an interactive robot model of the head and neck of a Deinonychus that creates the impression of a living dinosaur. The neck contains 6 actuated degrees of freedom and is composed of custom-made vertebrae. The vertebral column is modelled and controlled as a continuum arm. The project makes use of Popovic Lab's Hydro Muscles, which are elastic linear actuators that replicate muscular motion. These Hydro Muscles are powered by a custom hydraulic system and control the dinosaur neck by pulling on wire 'tendons' that are attached to key points on the neck. The team focused on elements that mimicked anatomical structures in order to develop a system to mimic lifelike behavior.

column5: Ryan Carnemolla, Anirban Mukherjee, Amrit Parmanand, Emily Staknis
column8: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping with Atlas
column10: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) is a powerful method for autonomously exploring new environments that had never been applied to humanoid robots. This project developed SLAM on the Atlas humanoid robot, allowing it to interact with and explore novel environments. The Atlas robot was programmed to create 3 dimensional maps of environments and localize itself within them. Due to constraints in time and safety the project was conducted mostly in simulation. Both stereo cameras and LiDar were used in experiments to identify the robot's surroundings and avoid obstacles. These sensors paired with the robot's locomotion allowed the Atlas robot to search and navigate unknown areas.

column5: Ryan Doyle, Irakli Grigolia, Kyria Nelson
column8: Creating an App for Audio Journal's Print Disabled Listeners
column10: As the world becomes more internet-oriented, it presents several unique challenges for people with blindness and visual impairments to access local news. Audio Journal is a radio reading service in Worcester, MA that broadcasts local news to blind and visually impaired people in Central Massachusetts. They wanted to improve access to their content by allowing their users to listen on demand without having to access their website. To achieve this goal, our project group created an iPhone app that was determined to be the best option towards improving accessibility for Audio Journal's current and future listeners. The app was developed and tested in phases over the course of 21 weeks, and is available on the App Store for download.

column8: "My Brain Does Not Function That Way'': Comparing Quilters' Perceptions and Motivations Towards Computing and Quilting
column10: While quilting has been used as a metaphor to help people understand Computer Science, the majority of these lessons have been done in the context of K-16 education. In our research we explore how this metaphor extends to already skilled craftspeople outside of formal learning environments. To investigate this, we first wanted to understand the similarities and differences between the ways that quilters think about quilting and the ways that they think about CS and computing more broadly. We held a focus group with seven quilters and asked them to compare their perceptions and experiences related to both fields. Through grounded theory analysis, we examined the conversation to understand the methods to best engage quilters in CS education.

column5: Dante Muzila, Revant Mahajan, Ankur Gupta, Andrew Euredjian
column6: Michael Gennert, Mahdi Agheli, Randy Paffenroth
column10: The goal of this project is to implement multi-modalism on the Solo8. In the current field of legged robotics, quadrupedal and bipedal robots are distinctly optimized for specific environments and tasks. This limits their adaptability across unstructured environments. In nature, we commonly see animals like primates, dogs, and bears overcome the inefficiencies of a single locomotion type by switching between quadrupedalism and bipedalism. However, very few robotic platforms can do this. A multi-modal robotic platform would provide additional adaptability in unstructured environments, broadening its potential applications. In this project, we extended an existing quadrupedal platform with the capability to transition into a bipedal stance.

column8: GaPA: A Program to Assist Novices with 3D Printing
column10: The 3D printing process can be daunting for novices, requiring knowledge of a multitude of settings to determine a part's optimal printing configuration. Current existing software tools overwhelm users with customizable settings. The goal of this project is to create a software application (GaPA) that will guide novices through the process of printing a part using an intuitive interface. It generates high quality G-Code for a printer, using automatically-selected settings based on user preferences. GaPA can serve as an introduction to slicing programs before users move to more complex software. GaPA has been tested with groups of WPI undergraduate students in Design and Manufacturing.

column8: Recreating the First Haptic Cinema Experience with Smartphones
column10: The goal of this project was to recreate the first haptic cinema experience through modern technology. We designed and implemented a mobile application that recreates the experience of Percepto, a haptic (tactile) cinema technology originally developed for Columbia's 1959 feature film "The Tingler". Utilizing Google's UI software development kit, Flutter, together with Firebase, and TypeScript, a client-server architecture was created that allows synchronized control of vibrations across multiple Android of iOS devices. Research with this project was used to understand the OS limitations of these mobile devices and in creating appropriate solutions.

column5: Jack Chase, Tim Giddings, Ryan Johnson, Sabrina Cacapit, Sullivan Boyd, Kevin Boenisch, Nick Alescio, Jack Ruddat, Ben Steeves, Kyle France, Nathaniel Bajakian, Tobias Schaeffer, Julia Duffield, Trevor Ninesling, Clayton Besch, Anavat Siamwala, Noah Parker
column7: Computer Science,Electrical & Computer Engineering,Mechanical Engineering,Robotics Engineering
column8: Design and Optimization of an Electric FSAE Vehicle
column10: This project represents the efforts of 17 students across four majors to design WPI's first Formula SAE Electric race car. Formula SAE Electric is an engineering design competition where collegiate teams from around the world build electric race cars to compete in events on and off the track. The most challenging aspect of this competition is the endurance event, where many cars experience failure. To complete this event, we considered reliability and serviceability from the systems level all the way down to individual component design. This is the first of two years of development, so our prototypes will be passed on to next year's team to be finalized and face extensive testing before going to competition.

column5: Zackary Fitzgibbon, Kate Fabrizio, Rakesh Veetekat
column10: The goal of this project is to extract key information from video data provided by a camera-mounted parachute and use it to help the parachute navigate in the air. The video provided by the parachute is utilized as input to a variety of algorithms that should instruct the parachute how to maneuver itself in the air to reach its destination. The reason why this method of navigation is being explored is because the traditional way of utilizing GPS to help the parachute plot a route to its destination can be unreliable, especially during instances of harsh weather. We researched and tested many algorithms that use the video data obtained from the parachute to develop a procedure that would rely on video more than GPS to steer the parachute.
